subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... Thanks for the response. I m honestly not sure what you mean is that there is no precise sound of any vowel phoneme in English. Such confusion is why I
messageBody:
Terry Smithwick wrote:
>
>
> All I'm saying is that there is no precise sound of any vowel phoneme
> in English. If you wish to map a particular IPA sound to a QS letter
> you may do so, but you will find situations where any particular
> mapping will be disagreed with. Any such mapping will be at least
> partly arbitrary. Feel free to ignore this reply if I'm still missing
> the point, I'm following this conversation with interest.
>

Thanks for the response. I'm honestly not sure what you mean "is that
there is no precise sound of any vowel phoneme in English." Such
confusion is why I am glad we are discussing the issue. Here's the
problem I am having. If you take the traditional orthograhy letter "o,"
there is certainly no one way to map this sound to IPA. There is
probably 5 or 6. That is the problem with traditional orthography.

If you take the letter "o" in "on," you have the same problem. There are
at least two ways to pronounce this vowel in American English, and maybe
even more in other countries.

But if you take the QS letter "On" (or "Ox"), #34, then their ought to
be only one way to pronounce this letter in an ideal context, which
means in isolation, or in a word in isolation. This mapping should not
be arbitrary, at least in ideal situations. When used in QS, #34 should
always be pronounced as the most back, most open, rounded vowel.

What is arbitrary is whether or not a speaker uses #34 when writing
"on," or uses #33 or #32. That would depend on his dialect.

Paul

Paul
